text: Heavy leaden skies over the arachnoid stands and floodlig of Elland Road stadium: home to Leeds United football clu And rain. Sheets of angry, Yorkshire rain.

Flashlights pop as DON REVIE, (late 40's), the most successful manager in English football, walks out in fron a pack of newspaper and TV REPORTERS. He is flanked by th Chairman of Leeds United, (MANNY CUSSINS, 60's), and seve other white-haired blazer-wearing members of the Board.
I'm just going to make a brief statement. CAPTION: "JULY 4th, 1974" REVIE stands under a large trophy cabinet, filled with th silverware he has won. REPORTERS wait: intimidated. Cowed REVIE (cont'd)

Yesterday afternoon at 3.00, I accepted the FA's offer to become the next manager of the England national football team. A gasp among the JOURNALISTS. A burst of flashlights. The BOARD MEMBERS look down at the floor in silence. Bereaved fathers losing their favourite son. REVIE (cont'd)

Obviously that involves me leaving Leeds United after 13 happy and successful years, which makes me very sad. I'd like to think I have built the club into a family and there must be sadness when anybody leaves a family. However, when one man goes, another steps into his place. I know who I think that person should be, the man to replace me, and I shall make my feelings clear to the directors. Thank you. No further comments. REVIE turns and walks out, a volley of REPORTERS shouting questions...
We're in a car. Tarmac passes beneath us. Roadmarkings. OVER THIS: the sound of a flat Teeside voice, singing alo with Frank Sinatra on the radio...
"Fly me to the Moon.."

Two young BOYS, (12, 9) stare out of car windows. Raindro on the panes of glass. Their father, BRIAN CLOUGH, (39), slick, modern, cocky, handsome. About as big a contrast t DON REVIE as it's possible to find, is up front. Driving.
(singing)
"And let me play among the stars.."
When are we there?
Any moment now. On the right. (singing)
"Let me see what spring is like..." The car turns a bend, and suddenly the floodlights and st of a football stadium come into view. The BOYS' eyes wide
There it is! Dad! There it is! The BOYS smile in excitement.
(singing)
"..on Jupiter and Mars.." `LEEDS UNITED FOOTBALL CLUB' written on the side of the stadium. CLOUGH smiles, then puts his foot down. The car accelerates past the turning. The BOYS' smiles fade.
Where are you going? Dad? You've missed it.
We've something else to do first. Won't take long. (singing)
CLO UGH (cont'd)
"In other words, hold my hand. In other words, darling kiss me..." The MUSIC continues as the car drives on, turning into th MUSIC of a television program..
The `CALENDER' front title sequence, a Yorkshire TV curre affairs program. We're in a TV studio. The presenter is AUSTIN MITCHELL, (40)..

Today we welcome Brian Clough as he starts his new job as manager of Leeds United, taking over from Don Revie - the most successful manager in the club's history, under whom Leeds have won everything..
..not QUITE everything. Not won the European Cup...
...but pretty much everything else. Daunted?
Daunted? Not at all, Austin. Looking forward to it.
The biggest challenge of your life, and you'll be without Peter Taylor, for the first time. Your lifelong professional colleague.
Yes, Pete's at Brighton now. He had the opportunity to come with me, but Brighton was his choice. Leeds was mine.
A surprising choice, some might say. Because you've been very vocal in your criticism of them over the years.
I have.
You've accused players of dirty tactics, cheating, dissent, foul play. You called Norman Hunter, Norman "Bites yer legs" Hunter, you've said Peter Lorimer falls when no one touches him...
And I was right.
I'm curious. Why do you now show such alacrity to joining them after such vituperative criticism of them for so long?
Goodness, it's going to take me half an hour to explain all those words for a start. Laughter from the camera CREW.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Football is a beautiful game, Austin. It needs to be played beautifully. I think Leeds have sold themselves short...
CLOUGH's interview continues on a TV in a sitting-room, w it is being watched by Don Revie, sitting in an armchair.

..they've been champions but they've not been good champions in the sense of wearing the crown well. They've not been loved. But then that's hardly surprising, given the type of operation there's been in place there.
CLOUGH continues...
Football clubs are like families, footballers are sensitive people. I'd like to bring a little warmth into the set-up...
"That type of operation?" I presume you're referring to Don Revie..
I am..
REVIE continues to watch the TV...

..who has long been regarded as a father figure in Leeds. And now you're coming in as the outsider, the enemy even, after all the things you've said in public, coming in and taking ouver as STEPfather.
MITCHELL looks up at CLOUGH...
Don't you expect some degree of resentment to this?

I would accept and expect a strangeness, initially, it's   perfectly normal. But it won't be long   before they realise I'm a fair man.   A kind man. And maybe under me they   can experience what it's like to   be in a happy family, after all.
How can you be sure they weren't happy with Don all along?
They wouldn't have played football that way if they were happy.
DON REVIE's eyes burn with indignation. He picks up a telephone, and angrily starts to dial..

Here they are. The Leeds PLAYERS. Long hair and long face Surly. Truculent. Dangerous. Out on the practice pitch. In the rain. Some doing warm-u exercises. Others milling dangerously in groups. Their na on their purple track suits.

head_text.subj: HUNTER, LORIMER, GILES, BATES, GRAY, CLARKE, BREMNER, MCQ

text: CLOUGH's car pulls up. He and his sons get out. A few wai press. Cameras. Lights. A few FANS with autograph books.
Where have you been, boss? JIMMY GORDON, CLOUGH loyal trainer, his face creased with anxiety..
Directors have been waiting more than an hour. C'mon..
JIMMY GORDON leads CLOUGH past the training pitch. CLOUGH looks out..
Morning lads! Lovely Yorkshire weather! (gestures shivering)

I tell you makes me want to jump on a plane right back to Majorca! CLOUGH laughs. The PLAYERS stare in silence. Squinting in drizzle. Condensation coming from their mouths. JOHNNY GILES stares. BILLY BREMNER spits and continues talking disrespectfully. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Not much of a welcome, was it? And not so much as a smile from Johnny Giles.
You're five days late!! And did you really need to say that about Majorca? (beat, changing the subject)
You know he was Revie's first choice for getting your job.
Who? Johnny Giles? CLOUGH looks over at GILES, who turns away, resumes training.... CLOUGH (cont'd)
Was he now? And Bremner?
Club Captain. Don's son and heir. His first born. You're never going to get any love from him. BREMNER, a flint-eyed Scot, stares at CLOUGH..
Great. Here's to happy fucking families.

JIMMY GORDON leads CLOUGH and his BOYS down a corridor, w countless photographs of DON REVIE hang on the walls. Hol silverware. They pass an open door, with a sign outside, `MANAGER. Mr DON. REVIE.' CLOUGH stops. Looks at the sign.
Then pushes open the door..

CLOUGH walks into the manager's office. The empty chair. bare desk. His desk. Don's desk. CLOUGH takes a seat in the chair. Presently, a middle-aged matron, JEAN REID, Don Revie's faithful SECRETARY for 13 years, appears in the doorway..
Any chance of a cup of tea, duck?
They're waiting for you. Upstairs. CLOUGH swings his feet on the desk.
Who's that?
The Directors.
For me? Why?
For the board meeting.
Let them wait. Now, how about that cup of tea? CLOUGH smiles sweetly, but JEAN stares at CLOUGH. She pointedly doesn't move. CLOUGH lowers his feet. CLOUGH (cont'd)
All right, I'll go then. Wouldn't want to get off on the wrong foot. CLOUGH walks over to the door. Looks at the desk. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Who's desk is that, love?
Yours, Mr. Clough.
Not mine. I didn't put it there, did
Mr. Revie's.
Let's get rid of it then, shall we? Chairs, too. The whole bloody lot. Think it would be best if there were nothing of his left here. CLOUGH reaches the door.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Were you his secretary?
I was. For thirteen happy years.
What's your name, pet?
Jean, Sir. Jean Reid.
In which case, no offence duck, but there's nothing I want typed on paper from you other than your resignation. She gasps.. CLOUGH (cont'd)

And you can change the locks on your way out. Don't want the ghost of troubled Don popping in now, do we? Rattling his chains. Scaring my young ones. CLOUGH puts his arms protectively round the BOYS, and lea them out of the door. JEAN REID stares, visibly shaken.

Half-a-dozen white-haired patriarchs sit at a large table Matching blazers and matching brass. MANNY CUSSINS, SAM BOLTON, BOB ROBERTS, SYDNEY SIMON, PERCY WOODWARD. Aldermen and Rotary club members. Masons and businessmen. CLOUGH enters the boardroom. Indicates to JIMMY GORDON to look after the BOYS outside. Inside: matching curtains an carpets.
Come in, Brian. CLOUGH sits down at the head of the table. Rubs his hands together..
What? No one going to offer me a drink? Like an undertakers in here. The DIRECTORS shoot looks at one another.
Why did you do it?
Do what?
The interview. For Yorkshire TV.
We've had a phone-call.
Not so much a phone-call. Bloody tirade.
From Don. They only went and rung him. And ran some of your quotes by him. About how unhappy the players were. What "bad champions". Looking for a response.
(shudders to himself)
Bloody got one, as well. He's gone berserk.
He had it coming. He shouldn't have done that piece in the Mirror should he? Saying he thought I was a daft choice.
He's entitled to his opinions.
And I'm entitled to mine.
(barks, flame on)
And I'm entitled to MINE. The room falls silent. That got everyone's attention.
CUSSINS (cont'd)
I hired you to do this job because I think you're the best young manager in the country...
Thank you. I'm the best old one, too.
...I also did it under the assumption that you'd be coming here wanting the best for the club. For the city of Leeds. So why do I still get the feeling this is all about you and Don?

Of course it's just about me and Don. Always has been. But instead of putting frowns on your foreheads, o ye elders of Leeds, in your blazers and brass fucking buttons, it should put big white Colgate smiles on your big white faces, because it means I won't sleep and won't eat until I take whatever that man's achieved and beaten it -- beaten it so I never have to hear the name "Don Fucking Revie" again -- beat it so the only name anyone sings in their Yorkshire ale houses, raising their stinking jars to their stinking mouths, is Brian Clough. Brian Clough uber fucking alles. Understand? The blazers and brass buttons, WHITE-HAIRED ELDERS of Lee stare at one another.
CLOUGH sits glued to a wireless in his front room.
..Ladies and Gentlemen, the draw for the third round of the FA Cup will now commence.. CLOUGH's eyes widen: he calls out to the others..
C'mon, Pete!
Number twenty-two..
Derby County, second division..
Here we go. That's us..!

PETER TAYLOR, seven years older than CLOUGH, his closest friend, his only true friend, appears breathlessly in the doorway back from a fish and chips run... ..followed by BARBARA, Clough's wife, and the three children..
Number six.. ON TV: the BLAZER-WEARING ELDER calls into the microphone
Leeds United!
Against mighty Leeds United..! CLOUGH and TAYLOR cry out in shock..
Leeds..!
Fucking hell..!
Don Revie's Leeds! Top of Division One! Here we bloody come!
The telephone rings. CLOUGH picks it up.. CLOUGH (cont'd) (already knowing it'll be SAM LONGSON)
What do you say to that, Mr. Chairman?
He's right. It's SAM LONGSON, Chairman of Derby County, (60's) looks like Krushchev, cue-ball head, voice like a power-drill, a tough haulage millionaire..
I can hear the cash registers now!
Happy days, Sir. Happy days.
You're not wrong, Brian. Take the family out for a meal. Go to The Mumtaz. Tell `em I'm paying.
CLOUGH hangs up the phone..
Put the fish and chips in the bin. Tonight's on Uncle Sam. We're going posh. Chicken fucking bhuna in town. General excitement. Everyone starts putting on their coat
CLOUGH stands with two men in overalls, indicating a fadi `Visitors' sign...
Right, you two, I want Billy Bremner and Johnny Giles to be able to read THAT... (indicates door-frames)
And this woodwork has seen better days..
`Crash', the following morning, CLOUGH bursts through swi doors, and into corridors with the CLEANERS...
Spick and span, understand? Wash these walls down. Give the floors a proper polish.
CLOUGH inspects the pitch with the HEAD GROUNDSMAN..
I want it perfect. Like a fucking carpet. We've got proper footballers coming. Who know how to keep the ball on the deck.
Well, you can't fucking train on it then.
The Derby PLAYERS train on a football pitch in a public p CLOUGH turns to TAYLOR..
You know he'll be making a file on us. A dossier.
Who?
Don Revie. Prepares a file on every game. Leaves nothing to chance. Knows every opponents formations. Strategies. Everything.
I've heard he's a superstitious twat. (calling out)
Ey..! Help him, someone HELP him..!
We grew up just a few streets apart, you know. In Middlesborough, close to Ayrsome Park. He'll have known my street, Valley Road - probably bought sweets from Garnetts Factory, where my dad worked.
Heard he wears the same suit to every game. His "lucky blue suit".
TAY LOR (cont'd)
And he doesn't care for ornamental birds. C'mon, who's covering him...!
The best manager in the country, Don Revie. Played for Sunderland, like me, as a centre-forward, like me, and England, like me.
(shouting out)
C'mon, give it and go!
Peas in a pod, me and Don. Two peas in a fucking pod.
CLOUGH in early. Before anyone. In shirtsleeves, sweeping corridors. Straightens photos on the wall.
CLOUGH polishing the sign, `VISITORS' on the dressing-roo door.
CLOUGH on his knees, scrubbing, cleaning baths in the visiting team's washrooms.

CLOUGH puts on his suit. Ties his tie. He takes a bottle vintage red wine from a cupboard. He places the bottles on his desk. Then puts two cut crys glasses on his desk. His and Don's. A flicker of jealousy on PETER TAYLOR's face, almost like wife - hurt that his friend is making such an effort for someone else. A knock on the door. JIMMY GORDON appears in the doorway.
They're here! (a confused look)
Well, almost..

CLOUGH rushes out of the doors, straightening his cuffs, straightening his hair, buttoning his jacket. First out t greet the arriving team. He turns the corner to see the LEEDS COACH a hundred yard down the street, the PLAYERS getting off the coach and walking towards him..
What are they doing?
They've run out of petrol.

No, it's that superstition, isn't it? Every away cup ties, Revie makes them walk the last hundred yards. TAYLOR mutters under his breath, "Soppy twat". CLOUGH cranes his neck. Watches DON REVIE, 40's. Thick-se Severe, forbidding, intimidating, in a huddle with his coaching staff, Les Cocker and Syd Owen. His henchmen. Hi assassins. His "Goodfellas". His right and left hand. CLOUGH walks towards him. Hand outstretched..

Welcome to Derby, Don. Pleasure to meet you. I'm Brian Clough. But REVIE walks past without shaking hands, without talki without even breaking stride.. ..and disappears into the stadium, deep in conversation w Les Cocker and Syd Owen. CLOUGH stares. Hand still outstretched. He looks over at PETER TAYLOR, who can't help smiling, `Forget it'. TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON walk off, but CLOUGH still stares REVIE in disbelief.
The LEEDS PLAYERS run out onto the pitch: HUNTER, MADELY, BREMNER, GILES, REANEY, JONES, in a line, waving to the crowd, turning North, South, East, West...
TAYLOR rubs his hands in excitement, "Here we go". But CL is miles away. Still cannot let the insult go. He stares at the visiting team dug-out..
REVIE and his lieutenants. Whispering among themselves. Huddled in thought. Huddled in strategy. Huddled in malevolence. Presently, the game starts. A roar from the crowd.
"Beeeep", the REF's whistle blows. A Derby PLAYER rolls i agony, cries out, a terrible, cynical challenge. Horrifie JIMMY GORDON and PETER TAYLOR up on thier feet in protest

Referee..! CLOUGH looks over to REVIE's bench. Sees REVIE and SYD OW quietly applauding the Leeds PLAYER. Encouraging more of same. As the Derby PLAYER is stretchered off.. Presently, RRROOOOAAAARRRRR goes up. Goal Leeds. REVIE an his henchmen get to their feet. Applauding. 1-0. TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON immediately start shouting out encouragement to the Derby PLAYERS, new instructions, as game restarts.. TAYLOR (cont'd)
C'mon, keep your shape! Close him down!
Think, Alan! To feet!

Now sent it out wide! CLOUGH doesn't join in. He continues to stare at REVIE in dugout. Suddenly: "Beeep!", whistle! Penatly Leeds! CLOUGH leaps off the be in outrage. Screaming, on his feel, protesting in disbeli

What? He didn't fucking touch him! Ref! He DIVED! He fucking dived! REVIE shaking hands with his COLLEAGUES. Smiling amongst themselves. Congratulating themselves. Celebrating. The inevitable roar as Leeds convert, followed by, "Beeeeeep", the sound of the final WHISTLE. CLOUGH stares disbelief. Robbed. Deflated. The REFEREE blows the whistle for the end of the game. CLOUGH watches as REVIE and SYD OWEN brush past, shaking PETER TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON's hands, (assuming TAYLOR's manager), on their way to the dressing-rooms, their minds already on their next game... CLOUGH stares as they go..
The two empty glasses waiting on the table.

Didn't say good-bye. Or pay me the respect of staying for a drink. Couldn't wait to get away. Through the front door we see: DON REVIE, SYD OWEN and LE COCKER walking to their bus, chuckling to themselves, dee discussion, already thinking about the next match.
Bloody cheats and all. Neither of those goals should have been allowed. But CLOUGH doesn't hear...
Just going to have to beat them, Pete. Beat him it's the last thing I do.
We need to get into the same division first.
We need someone with a good head. Experience.
I know. Our lot were like headless chickens out there today. CLOUGH turns to TAYLOR...
First thing Monday morning, I want you to go and find me that player. A wise head. TAYLOR opens his mouth, is about to protest.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
And don't worry about the money. That's my problem. Just you go and find him. CLOUGH's face: watching the Leeds PLAYERS board the bus..
CLOUGH's face: staring out at the Leeds PLAYERS waiting o the training pitch. A deep breath.
Right. Better go and make myself known. CLOUGH removes his jacket. JIMMY GORDON and CLOUGH's SONS watch as he walks out onto the training pitch...
CLOUGH walks out into the drizzle and towards the LEEDS PLAYERS..
(up-beat, clapping hands)
All right, gentlemen, gather around, please. The players truculently gather round. CLOUGH watches them notes their mood, then.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
I might as well tell you now.
CLO UGH (cont'd)

You lot may all be internationals and have won all the domestic honours there are to win under Don Revie, but as far as I'm concerned, the first thing you can do for me is to chuck all your medals and all your caps and all your pots and all your pans into the biggest fucking dustbin you can find because you've never won any of them fairly. You've done it all by bloody cheating. Silence from the PLAYERS.. CLOUGH (cont'd)

Mr. William Bremner. You're the captain. And a good one. But you're no good to the team and you're no good to me if you're suspended. I need you fit for every game, and I want good, clean, attractive football from my captain. Setting an example. CLOUGH turns to PETER LORIMER. CLOUGH (cont'd)

Mr. Lorimer, I hope you were listening because you're as good a footballer as I've ever seen, but you know how I feel about the way Don let you harangue referees, fall over when you've not been touched, protesting and pointing, trying to get other players booked. We'll have no more of that. CLOUGH turns to JOHNNY GILES.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
And you, Irishman. God gave you skill, intelligence, and the best passing ability in the game. What God did not give you was six studs to wrap around another player's knee.
I don't know what you're talking about. CLOUGH turns to NORMAN HUNTER...
But you do, though, "Bites yer Legs".
People kick me, I kick them back.
Not with me as manager. Do that on my watch, you'll be fined and stuck in the reserves. (to all the PLAYERS)

Things are going to be a little different around here. Without Don. Might feel a little strange at first. Might pinch a little. Like a new pair of shoes. But if you want your grandchildren to remember you for being something other than the dirty buggers you all were, if you want to be loved as REAL champions, WORTHY champions, you're going to have to work. And improve. And change. (nods to JIMMY GORDON)
Now let's start off by playing some seven-a-sides. PLAYERS stare at one another. Bristling. Disbelieving loo
Don never did that.

Well, I'm not Don. And from now on I never want to hear that man's name again. Ever. Next player who mentions it, or what he did or didn't bloody do in the good ol' days, will spend a week cleaning my boots. (clapping hands)
Seven-a-side. Keep it nice and clean, and sensible. No fifty-fifty's. CLOUGH sees that one side is a man short.. CLOUGH (cont'd)

Right, I'll play myself. You might learn something, Irishman. Two hundred and fifty-one goals in two hundred and seventy-four starts. CLOUGH skillfully traps the ball between his feet, flips up onto this head - down onto his chest, then "WHAM" voll it into a distant goal.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Like to see Don fucking Revie do that, eh? CLOUGH removes his track suit trousers, rolls his neck. J GORDON quickly divides the players into two teams, blows whistle..
The game starts. CLOUGH, leading by example, anxious to p himself, is soon darting about, calling out... CLOUGH (cont'd) (clapping hands)

Here, son. To feet. Keep it simple. Think and give. On the deck. Nice and crisp. Yes, to me, Sniffer. To me. CLARKE passes the ball. But it's a fifty-fifty. Another player bears down on CLOUGH..who refuses to pull out.. "CRUNCH", a bone-shaking tackle from "BITES YER LEGS". CLOUGH (cont'd)
Oh, Jeeeeeesussss!!! CLOUGH is flattened. Rolls around on the floor. JIMMY GOR runs up to NORMAN HUNTER..

Fucking matter with you? He said no fifty-fifty's. HUNTER aggressively steps forward. Nose to nose. He is immediately flanked by other aggressive Leeds PLAYERS. Crowding the referee. Intimidating him.
What are you going to do about it? Book me? JIMMY GORDON backs off, visibly frightened. CLOUGH lies o the floor. In agony. Holding his knee.
CLOUGH listens to the PLAYERS laughing at him. Disrespect him. His face darkens.
(mimicking)
"Two hundred and fifty-one goals in two hundred and seventy-four starts." The sound of coarse, cruel laughter among the LEEDS PLAYE JIMMY GORDON appears, CLOUGH's two SONS in tow..
I've got what you were looking for. JIMMY holds up a large parcel wrapped in brown paper. CLOUGH's expression changes.
What about the petrol?
In the boot of the car.
Good lad.
CLOUGH limps down a corridor. In a thunderous mood. Holdi the parcel. PEOPLE scatter.
The door flies open. CLOUGH storms into his office. He wa over to the desk. DON REVIE's desk. He unwraps the parcel, and takes out an axe.
Stand back. CLOUGH's SONS watch as their father violently swings the down onto the desk. The sickening sound of splintering wo
CLOUGH watches the desk burn in a small bonfire outside. MANNY CUSSINS and several DIRECTORS walk out. They are surprised to see CLOUGH by the fire holding an axe...
Everything all right?
(sunny, waving with the axe)
Fine thank you, Mr. Cussins. CLOUGH smiles politely, then turns, and walks to his car. DIRECTORS watch..
"Rrrriiinnnggg", the phone rings. CLOUGH and his FAMILY a having Sunday lunch. BARBARA CLOUGH looks up..
Not now, love - please? "Rrrrriinnngggg". The phone rings. CLOUGH tries to ignore
But it might be Pete.
(rolls eyes)
Of course it's Pete. "Rrrriiinnngggg", CLOUGH tries to eat, then..
But it might be important. (to NIGEL)
C'mon, eat your carrots. For your Mother. CLOUGH gets up. Walks out of the room..
PETER TAYLOR, similarly in disgrace with his family, similarly unable to go a single Sunday lunch without call CLOUGH, whispers down the phone, terrified of his wife..
You asked me to find a player with a good head. Experience. (whispering, furtive)
I've found one! He's perfect. Dave Mackay.
Dave Mackay?!? He's a hundred and fucking fifty.
I admit he's not young.
Not young? He's old as fucking time!
But he's clever, keeps the ball well. And passes it better than anyone alive.
A voice calls from TAYLOR's dining-room..
Pete...! That's enough! Come back!
(looks left and right)
He's the one, Brian.
You sure?
Never been more sure of anything in my life.
All right, I'll talk to Longson in the morning.
We haven't got until morning. Hearts have already made him an offer. Want him as their manager. Apparently they've already agreed terms.
Well, what did you fucking call me for then?
Because when I asked Bill Nick how done the deal was - he said ninety- nine per cent. CLOUGH's face.
Meaning he hasn't signed.
Exactly.
BARBARA CLOUGH rolls her eyes, puts down her cutlery, and calls out..
All right, Brian. Enough. Come back now.. No answer. BARBARA tuts to herself. Gets up from the tabl She walks out of the dining-room, calling out..
BARBARA (cont'd)
C'mon, that's enough...
..and into the hall. BARBARA stops. She looks left and ri No sign.
Brian..? Love..?

CLOUGH and TAYLOR emerge from a roadside cafe and walk towards their car. They've missed Sunday lunch. So it's Crisps. Sweets. Fizzy drinks. Almost childlike. Happier i one another's company than with their own families.
Where would we play him?
In the middle of the park. Somewhere he can see everything, use his loaf, and tell the kids what to do.
We'll play him as a sweeper, then.
(eating crisps)
Aye. They climb into the waiting car...
Won't have to run about too much. And what's all this I hear about a tie shop?
He's got a tie shop, hasn't he? In London. Which he spends two days a week at. CLOUGH starts the engine...
Fucking tie shop?
It's his "nest egg". For the future.
No one's going to be wearing fucking ties in twenty years time. CLOUGH and TAYLOR both giggle. Like kids. The car pulls off... CLOUGH (cont'd)
Hope his footballing brain is better than his business brain.
CLOUGH's car pulls up outside a house in a quiet terraced road in North London. TAYLOR checks it against the addres a piece of paper. The two men get out of the car...
You know it's illegal. To sign someone on the sabbath.
Is it? (immediately cautious)
Then perhaps we should just shake on it today? And sign tomorrow?
What? And let Hearts in again in the morning? Fuck off. (producing contracts)
I'm not leaving here without a signature. CLOUGH and TAYLOR walk up the garden path.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
You'd bloody DO that, too - wouldn't you? Come all this way, then just "shake hands"? (shaking head)
Dear oh dear. What would you DO without me?
Hey, you would never have FOUND him if it weren't for me. CLOUGH stops, rings the doorbell. Looks at TAYLOR.
Good job we're both wearing ties.
`Snap', the door opens to reveal DAVE MACKAY, a thick set dark-haired bull of a man, with a thick Scots accent. CLO smiles ear to ear.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Jehova's Witness, Dave! May the Lord be with you!
Who the bloody hell are you?
My name's Brian Clough, and I once had the pleasure of playing for England against you in an Under-23 match.
I remember you now. You had a black eye, a right bloody shiner. (a beat)
And never stopped fucking talking! What are you doing here?
Come to talk to you about the Promised Land, Dave. Land of Milk and Honey. It's a little place up the M1 called Derby. (a beat)
May we come in?
CLOUGH, TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON training with the Derby PLAYERS. SAM LONGSON, (late 60's), Chairman of Derby Coun approaches, visibly angry..
Dave Mackay??
You don't look happy, Uncle Sam.
I'm not. What were you thinking? Going over my head like that? Why didn't you call?
Because you'd have said `no'.
Bloody right I'd have said `no'. The man's bloody crocked.
Pete reckons he's good for three more years.
Is he fuck. He's broken more bones than Evel Knievel.
Trust me, Mr. Chairman. It's money well spent. LONGSON turns and double-takes....
And who the FUCK are they?
That'd be Messrs. McGovern and O'Hare.
Afternoon/Hello!
(almost passing out)
Where did they come from?
My old stomping grounds. Hartlepools and Sunderland. Very reasonable, too. CLOUGH smiles.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Just doing what's best for the club.
That'd be MY club, Brian. MY club.
`Flash', DAVE MACKAY, JOHN MCGOVERN and JOHN O'HARE weari Derby strip, poses under the Derby County sign for photographs with CLOUGH and TAYLOR..
CLOUGH and TAYLOR watch from the touchline as their new t led by MACKAY plays in a match. CLOUGH watches in admiration...

You're a genius, Pete. Bloody genius. How did you see it? On the training ground: DAVE MACKAY, barrel-chested and older, voice like a bullhorn, is already bossing about th young players, urging them to "think"..
Dunno. It was just obvious. McGovern in midfield, Mackay at the back, O'Hare up front. The skewer isn't it? In the shish kebab. CLOUGH watches MACKAY passing the ball, creating space..
It's beautiful. A thing of fucking beauty!! CLOUGH grabs TAYLOR's head, kisses him. OVER THIS: we fad the roar from the crowd...
GOAL!! Derby score. CLOUGH and TAYLOR leap to their feet.
GOAL!! Derby score. CLOUGH and TAYLOR leap to their feet.
GOAL!! Derby score. CLOUGH and TAYLOR leap to their feet.
Of DERBY winning the championship. Of NEWS STATIONS announcing it in the Midlands.
A large, swanky house, as befits the multi-millionaire ow of a successful haulage business.
SAM LONGSON, BRIAN CLOUGH, PETER TAYLOR and DAVE MACKAY a all celebrating with all their families. The trophy is centre-stage. CLOUGH sings a Sinatra classi
"Love and marriage, love and marriage, it's an institute you can't disparage.." To everyone's amusement: CLOUGH sings to PETER TAYLOR, no his own wife.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
"Try, try, try to separate them, it's an illusion. Try, try, try and you will only come to this conclusion.." In another corner: MACKAY is amiably ribbing LONGSON..
..."the man's crocked", "older than time" "broken more bones than Evel Knievel?"

All right, I admit it, I was wrong. LONGSON starts eating his trademark felt hat. Much cheeri as he munches in disgust and swallows with difficulty. Suddenly, DAVE MACKAY looks up, sees the television. Call for quiet!! ON TV: a live awards presentation. From London. DON REVIE being presented with an award...
..for Leeds to win the First Division title, and for me to be named as English Manager of the year...feels like a dream come true... CLOUGH watches. His expression changes. His eyes burn int REVIE's.

You enjoy it, Don. Go home, put your feet up and fucking enjoy it. There's a good lad. Because we'll be in the First Division next season. And we're going to have you! Loud CHEERS from LONGSON, TAYLOR, MACKAY and CLOUGH. OVER THIS: we fade in the sound of roaring...
ARCHIVE TV FOOTAGE: Wembley Stadium on Charity Shield day The opening of the 1974/5 season.

The twin towers of Wembley Stadium, the cathedral of English football on a glorious late-summer's day... good afternoon everyone, it's the Charity Shield, the opening Saturday of the 1974 season, and a first chance to get a look at Brian Clough's Leeds...
DON REVIE is being interviewed by a TV JOURNALIST in sheepskin coat and headphones..
Will you be supporting Leeds today, Don?
You'd expect nothing less having been their manager for 13 years. But the fact is I'm here today as manager of England...
Do you have any advice to give your successor, Brian Clough, before his first game? A mischievous smile barely perceptible of REVIE's face..
Win. The people of Leeds are used to winning.
CLOUGH with the LEEDS TEAM in the dressing-room before ki off. PLAYERS changing. The stink of Ralgex. PHYSIOS banda the injured. JIMMY GORDON massaging one or two players.
Right, the team for today is: Harvey in goal, Reaney, Cherry, Bremner, McQueen, Hunter, Lorimer, Clarke, Jordan, Giles, Gray. CLOUGH folds a piece of paper. A flicker of vulnerability CLOUGH (cont'd)

Obviously all eyes will be on us to see how things have changed. Without Don. What might be different under me. Let's show them some of the things we've been working on. Our changes in attitude, too. Our new outlook. New discipline. New approach. (a beat)
Let's see some of you playing with a smile. Team talk over: the PLAYERS put on their shoes. Make fina preparations.
The two teams are limbering up in the tunnel. CLOUGH take his place ahead of BILLY BREMNER..
Of course, it goes without saying I'd like you to continue as Club Captain. Silence. BREMNER continues to limber up... CLOUGH (cont'd)
You know, son, I've nothing but the highest regard for you as a player. They PLAYERS get the instruction to walk out, towards the roar of the crowd... CLOUGH (cont'd)
In fact, I wrote you a card saying as much. Did you not get it? From Majorca? The roar of the CROWD grows louder... CLOUGH (cont'd)
Saying how excited I was to be taking this job. How much I thought we could achieve together. And inviting you and your family down to our place in Calla Major any time you like?
Never got it. They walk out into the ROAR of the crowd....
DON REVIE sits in the stadium watching as: CLOUGH leads his Leeds PLAYERS out. 67,000 FANS screaming shouting. A stony-faced BREMNER behind him.

CLOUGH's face in close-up. Singing the National Anthem. He sees REVIE in the crowd. CLOUGH's eyes. REVIE's eyes. All around them, (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) 67,000 belting out "Go Save The Queen". But there might as well not be.
It's just REVIE and CLOUGH.
ARCHIVE FOOTAGE: the National Anthem finishes. A great RO goes up.
The game is underway. The T.V. match COMMENTATORS can har believe what they are seeing, (we catch snippets of FLICKERING ARCHIVE FOOTAGE on their monitors)...

Kevin Keegan goes to ground....rolling around on the pitch....that almost looked like Johnny Giles's fist made contact with Kevin Keegan's face...it was!...the referee's pulled out his book...now a fight has broken out!
On the pitch: BREMNER and KEEGAN have started fighting..
Billy Bremner of Leeds and Kevin Keegan of Liverpool have come to blows...
CLOUGH watches from the dug-out. Unable to believe his ey
For fuck's sake..
...the referee is talking to his linesman..! He's sending them off! The referee is sending off both players..
BILLY BREMNER walks off, angrily removing his shirt..
ARCHIVE FOOTAGE: Liverpool lift the CUP aloft. Delirious cheering from their FANS...
The Leeds coach had pulled up and the players are all hav a piss-break. Among them CLOUGH..
(over his shoulder)

Because losing wasn't enough, was it? You only had to be the first Englishman to be sent off at Wembley. Our CAMERA widens to reveal BILLY BREMNER pissing in line with NORMAN HUNTER and JOHNNY GILES..
(through gritted teeth)
Not fucking English.

There I am making a big song and dance to the media about our new approach. Our new attitude. Our new ethics. And you turn the place into fucking Verdun. My CAPTAIN. Silence. CLOUGH shakes himself dry. CLOUGH (cont'd)
What am I going to do if they suspend you? You're my best player. I tell you, I've a mind to fine you two weeks wages!
You can't do that! Mr. Revie always paid all our fines.
Well he's not fucking here now, is he?
No, he's not. BREMNER, GILES AND HUNTER turn. Walks back towards the bu BREMNER (cont'd)
More's the fucking pity.
DON REVIE's face: he watches through a window in Elland R as....

The Derby Coach arrives. Hydraulic brakes HISSSSSSS. Door open. Boots, shoes, walk down steps. BRIAN CLOUGH, PETER TAYLOR and the Derby Army disembark. CLOUGH's face: as he looks up at the writing on the side the stadium. LEEDS UNITED F.C.
Some PLAYERS getting dressed. CLOUGH, TAYLOR and JIMMY GO massaging others. Shin-pads. Water-bottles.

Right, last time there was a whole division between you and Leeds. Not now. Not today. Today we're here as Second Division champions, and equals with Leeds. John McGovern and Billy Bremner, EQUALS. Kevin Hector and Johnny Giles, EQUALS. Alan Hinton and Peter Lorimer, John O'Hare and Paul Madely. EQUALS. Now, c'mon, chins up. Chests out. We can take this fucking lot. The PLAYERS clatter out, studs rattling down the tunnel, the roar of the CROWD..
CLOUGH and TAYLOR in a deserted bar. Alone. A television plays in the corner. DON REVIE's face on TV...

...obviously it's a terrific achievement for Derby, being promoted to the First Division, but the truth is Leeds United have an unfortunate habit of reminding them just how far they still have to go..
Arrogant twat..
But he's right. Five nothing. They made us look like fools today. And what was John O'Hare doing? Letting Madeley bully him like that.
CLO UGH (cont'd)
Push him around. Madeley's half his bloody size. O'Hare needs to toughen up. He's from Scottish dockyards, isn't he? And what about John McGovern? He was useless in the middle. Who's idea was that?
Yours.

He was all over the place. Like the Wandering Jew. Giving the ball to anyone BUT his own. We need a ball player, a natural in midfield. Who'll hold onto it. Keep possession. We're giving it away too easily.
Someone like Colin Todd.
(sharp intake)
Oooh, now you're talking. Lovely pair of feet.
I've heard he wants out of Sunderland, too. They're all jumping ship up there. CLOUGH thinks for a moment, then...
Well, go on then. Sign him.
What? We can't. Longson's already told us. Club's in debt.
Bollocks to that. I've not brought us all the way to the First Division just to sit there mid-table, and be cannon fodder for sides like Leeds. Sign the man.
Hang on, hang on, careful...
I'll handle bloody Longson.
CLOUGH is working a session with the Derby PLAYERS. A car screeches into the car park behind. A red-faced, apoplect SAM LONGSON gets out..
A hundred and seventy grand?!? For Colin fucking Todd?!?
Correction, the ALMIGHTY Colin Todd. The best technical footballer in the country.
A salary of three hundred quid a week? You can't pay a footballer that!!
That's the way things are going, Uncle Sam. Football's all about money now.
I told you never to go over my head again.
Had no choice. Windows opened up. You were in the bloody West Indies.
WindowS? You mean there were others?!?
Messrs. Gemmell and Hennessy. Two PLAYERS turn and wave to LONGSON..
Afternoon!/Hello!
(eyes popping/apoplectic)
For fucks SAKE!
Let me ask you a question, Uncle Sam. What did you come into football for?
To support the football club in MY HOME TOWN. The club I've supported ALL MY LIFE.
Well, I'm sure we all admire your loyalty...
What I DIDN'T come into it for was to be lectured by a cocky little twat from the North East.

But the way I see it, there's no point being in this game unless you want to beat the best, and be the best, and that's all the people of Derby want. To see their team on top of the tree, Derby, Derby Uber Alles, and if it's really their interest you have at heart, not just impressing your friends in the Director's box, I suggest you keep your eyes on your road haulage business, keep your opinions to yourself and start signing some fucking cheques, there's a good lad. Leave the running of this football club to the professionals.

But professionals DON'T run the club, Brian, the Chairman does. And if it's true, that football is all about money, and that's the way it's going, that's suits us Chairmen just fucking fine..because we're the ones who've got it. SAM LONGSON lights a cigar, and walks off.
The Leeds coach pulls into the Derby car park. Doors open DON REVIE and SYD OWEN disembark. Followed by the Leeds PLAYERS. Smoking. Side-burns. Long- haired assassins one and all.
CLOUGH and TAYLOR watch from an upstairs corridor window.
See they've driven all the way into the car park this time.
It's not a cup game, is it? CLOUGH and TAYLOR look at one another, "Nutter".
An atmosphere of expectation and excitement. Outside, the sound of the crowd. The sound of tannoy announcements. CLOUGH goes to JOHN MCGOVERN..
You know what your job is today?
Yes, Boss. Stay in position. Keep the shape. "Stop being the Wandering Jew".
Good lad. And enjoy it. You deserve to. You've worked hard this week. CLOUGH moves to JOHN O'HARE. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Clear about what you're doing today?
Be big. Be strong. Any chance I get, flatten Paul fucking Madely.
Good lad. He bullies you, you bully him back. And near post for the corners we worked on.
Yes, Boss. CLOUGH moves to another PLAYER. (his new signing, COLIN T
Understand what I want from you today, son?
(smiles)
I should, Mr. Clough. It's simple enough.
Go on, let's hear it.
"To be Colin fucking Todd, the best technical footballer in the country." Laughter in the dressing-room.
There, how could you forget that? Now come on.. (clapping hands)
Up and at `em! CLOUGH holds the door open, shaking each and every one of PLAYERS' hands as they clatter out into the tunnel..

CLOUGH sits in his dug-out. While JIMMY GORDON and TAYLOR calling out instructions to the Derby players on the pitc CLOUGH stares at REVIE and his lieutenants in their neighbouring dug-out. Presently...CLOUGH's view, and our frame is filled by two wheel-chairs carrying disabled/learning difficulties FANS wearing rosettes... The wheel-chair FAN looks at CLOUGH for a beat, then violently shakes a rattle...

CLOUGH's face: shocked. Then, all of a sudden.... "RRRRROOOOOOOAAAAAARRRRRR", a roar goes up. Goal Leeds. R and his henchmen leap to their feet, delighted. Applaudin The WHEEL-CHAIR FAN screams with delight. Makes a `wanker gesture in CLOUGH's face. CLOUGH's face: darkening like thunder.
The DERBY PLAYERS sit in the dressing-room. Shaking. Terrified. Trying to hide, find shelter, find protection.
Already fearing the rocket they will get, the lash of his tongue.. Presently, the door opens, and CLOUGH walks in, carrying bottle of brandy, Remy Martin.

Congratulations, lads! Beautiful! That was as perfect a half of terrible football as I've ever seen. The plan you've obviously been hatching to get me the sack has worked a treat, so you deserve a little celebration... CLOUGH pours brandy into a tea-cup, gives it to a PLAYER. CLOUGH (cont'd)
You do want me to get the sack?
No, Boss.
Then why the fuck did you give it to their most dangerous player, Johnny fucking Giles?
I didn't see him. CLOUGH turns to another PLAYER, (JOHN O'HARE), pours him shot of cognac...
You want me to get the sack, Mr O'Hare?
No, Boss.
That open goal? Looked like a deliberate fucking miss to me. A miss to get your manager the sack. CLOUGH turns to a third PLAYER, (COLIN TODD), hands him a cup.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
You do want me to get the sack, Mr. Todd?
No.
No what?
No, Boss.
The amount of bloody money I paid for you, I must have been out of my mind. You can't even keep on your feet.
No, Boss. CLOUGH turns, and faces the room.

You've all done a terrific job of getting me the sack. So I'm not letting you out of here for the second half, until you've finished the bottle. The PLAYERS stare at one another, holding their drinks. CLOUGH (cont'd)
The PLAYERS nervously down their drinks. CLOUGH exits..
CLOUGH walks out to see PETER TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON wai - who were listening through the door..
You can't do that!! CLOUGH winks...
Can't I? Just you fucking watch me!! CLOUGH storms off. PETER TAYLOR is left alone. Looks pale Momentarily holds his chest...
You all right?
Yeah....fine. TAYLOR indicates JIMMY's cigarettes.
TAYLOR (cont'd)
Giz a fag.
The Derby PLAYERS run out, belching, watched and encourag by PETER TAYLOR... JIMMY GORDON emerges from the dressing-room, holding the empty bottle of Scotch...
(to TAYLOR)
Where's he gone now?

CLOUGH pacing in his office. Unable to watch. Like an expectant father. Presently the building reverberates with a large... RRRROOOAAAARRRRRRRRR. A goal. But scored by whom? Derby or Leeds? CLOUGH looks up at the clock. The clock on the wall shows it's 4.20. Visibly anxious, CLOUGH starts pacing again. Presently, another deafening...

The building is almost brought to it's foundations.. CLOUGH looks up. Desperate to know. Derby or Leeds? But it's only 4.35. Game still not over. Not by a long wa CLOUGH carries on pacing. Walks from one side of the room the next. Left to right. Right to left. Then, another stadium-shaking..
CLOUGH looks up at the clock. 4.55. This is intolerable. The game must be over now. CLOUGH cannot bear it a moment longer. He opens the door.

CLOUGH walks down a corridor. Then runs. Then checks hims Slows down. Dignity. Dignity. But still walks as fast as can. CLOUGH turns a corner to the dressing-rooms and the tunne then sees PETER TAYLOR up ahead entering the tunnel from pitch with several Derby PLAYERS.. CLOUGH stops. TAYLOR looks up. Sees CLOUGH. Their eyes me CLOUGH's eyes. TAYLOR's eyes. Words are not necessary. TAYLOR's smile says it all. CLOU runs towards TAYLOR. The two men embrace.
And..?
Who scored?

O'Hare. A brace. Oh, Brian, you should have seen his first. Turns Bremner inside out, nutmegs Madeley for good measure. It was beautiful. You'd think he'd been born in Rio de Janeiro, not Aber-bloody-deen.. CLOUGH and TAYLOR walk off down the corridor. TAYLOR (cont'd)
What made you go for the Brandy?
They were just nervous. Shitting themselves. You could tell.
You're a bloody genius. I tell you what, Bri - if we can beat this lot, we can go all the way.

head_text.subj: A TELEPROMPTER RATTLES ACROSS OUR SCREEN

text: Derby win against Ipswich Town - 1-0

head_text.subj: A TELEPROMPTER RATTLES ACROSS OUR SCREEN

text: Derby win against Sheffield United - 4-0

head_text.subj: A TELEPROMPTER RATTLES ACROSS OUR SCREEN

text: Derby beat Huddersfield Town - 3-0
A NEWSREADER announces that Derby County have won the Fir Division Championship.
The DERBY PLAYERS celebrate in a communal bath, holding t trophy, drinking champagne. Spraying one another with wat
CLOUGH, TAYLOR and ROY MACFARLAND hold aloft a large trop travelling on board an open-top bus, through Derby. The w town has taken to the streets.
CLOUGH, still celebrating, and still surrounded by PLAYER and FANS
Derby County winning the championship is a victory for decency, for honesty and for football. Because they don't pull shirts, or nudge people in the back in the box.
CLO UGH (cont'd)
They don't protest every decision, chop, hack or bully - unlike some teams I could mention - beginning with the letter `L'.. JOURNALISTS laugh... CLOUGH (cont'd)
If you ask me, the best thing for British football, the quickest way to clean it up, would be fore dirty sides like Leeds to be sent down for a spell in Division Two.
DON REVIE speaking to JOURNALISTS outside his home..

I haven't personally heard Mr. Clough's comments, but they have been reported to me, and our solicitors are looking into them. If I could offer Mr. Clough some advice ...I think he'd be better off keeping his opinions to himself...some of these allegations against Leeds United and his fellow professionals are an absolute disgrace...
CLOUGH appearing on half-a-dozen TV shows. Quick, controversial, charismatic, witty. A natural media star, intercut our actor with the genuine archive footage)
Don Revie? Ooooh. (shudders playfully)
Don't mention that name to me.
It's really like the other House of Commons. You hate to mention him. Why?
I hate to mention him why? Because he's a very talented man and I don't like him. The audience laughs. CLOUGH (cont'd)

He's a very, very talented man and his record is unsurpassable. But I just happen not to like him. And I don't like the way he goes about football either. Football is a game of opinion and there are perhaps people in your profession who don't like the way you do your bit.
Sure.
And er... it makes the game go round. Half the country don't like a Labour government. It just happens that the other half do.
Why don't you want me to ask why you don't like him?
Because I can't tell you. It's impossible. We'd get closed down, David. JOHN SADLER, pipe smoking football journalist, sits in a television studio, (CALENDER)..
Brian, you've been called big-headed, arrogant, brash, the lot -
By your profession, John, yeah.
Sure. And a whole of it right too.
And a whole lot of it wrong.
Fine. I'll concede that. So how would you define your approach to management, apart from being brilliant? All laugh.
(laughing, rubbing eye)
Good lad. Thank you for the compliment. It's very, very difficult when you get asked a question like that. DAVID COLEMAN, black and white footage, speaking into a bakolite telephone..
You've achieved something here that most managers struggle for years to achieve this. It's come to you very young. Are you surprised?
CLOUGH sits at home, his SON on his lap.
Suprised, David..but more than surprised, delighted. It's nice isn't it. For the good guys to win for once.
Which for you was the most important match to win and the best performance from your point of view...
Beating Leeds United, obviously. Always a particular pleasure that.
Brian, you've also done it on comparatively small gates, which I know has niggled you a little bit during the season.

Niggled me, David, it's absolutely made me blazing. To be honest, I know what I want to achieve, I know what the people of Derby want us to achieve, but when you've got a chairman not wanting to put his hand in his pocket... MICHAEL PARKINSON, the highest rating talk show on TV.. CLOUGH (cont'd)

You ever see eighty five or perhaps ninety percent of chairmen talking - I'd love a few chairmen on your programme occasionally - I believe the very sight of them brings the game into disrepute (some clap in the audience). And every time they open their mouths it kills it. Because the very thing they've given me a lot of stick about over the years - about talking too much and going on television too much, there are the very people who can put two words together and its rather embarrassing to me that a man - or men - can stop me talking to people like you. I love football. It's deep, it goes right down through. It's in every nerve, vein, you name it. It consumes me. And when I have to come and talk about I like the passions of football to come out. Because there are not enough in the game.
CLO UGH (cont'd)
I like a bit of the honesty, I like a bit of the truth. I accept without any shadow of a doubt that I talk too much, apart from on this show. Laughter.
How do you react when someone says "Boss, you're doing it wrong?"
I say, "How do you think it should be done?" We talk about it for twenty minutes, then we decide I was right.

head_text.subj: BLACK AND WHITE ARCHIVE TV FOOTAGE OF MOHAMMED ALI

text: ..the world knows who I am. The world knows I talk a lot.
MOH AMMED ALI (con t'd)
But there's some fellow in London, England named...."Brian Clough"... (audience laughter)
Anyway I heard all the way in America, They say he's another Mohammed Ali. Well, there's just ONE Mohammed Ali. I want you to know... (jabbing finger)
Clough...you are not taking my job. I'm the talker. Now, Clough...enough.
CLOUGH and TAYLOR, surrounded by FRIENDS and FAMILIES, wi flowers, telegrams, bottles of champagne, boxes of cigars Watching the Mohammed Ali on television.
Are you going to stop it?
No, I want to fight him! They roar with laughter. Cheers and celebration. Everyone roughing up CLOUGH's hair, patting him on the back.

The QUEEN's face. Full-frame. Beside her PRINCE PHILIP. A portrait of Her Majesty the Queen and HRH the Duke of K hangs on an oak-pannelled wall: the Patron and the Presid of the Football Association.. Beneath the portrait: a long table in a boardroom. An aus six-man disciplinary committee of the FA. Blazers and buttons. Whiskers and power. Aldermen, Freemasons, Generals, white-hair and golden buttons. Admirals, Presidents and Vice-Presidents. Sitting in front of the committee... BILLY BREMNER and BRIAN CLOUGH. Like schoolchildren..
William Bremner, your conduct in the Charity Shield match was deplorable and cannot be tolerated.
It was.

We understand Leeds are taking disciplinary action against you internally, however the Football Association has to be seen to make an example. We have therefore decided to impose a fine of five hundred pounds.. CLOUGH's face: a victorious look.
Thank you..
...and a suspension until September 30th... "Bang", he brings down a gavel. CLOUGH's face: the smile fades..
(disbelieving laugh)
What? September 30th? That's more than a month? Thats six bloody weeks??
I'll make it seven if you carry on with language like that..
C'mon, double the fine. Treble it. Anything. Don't suspend him for that long. He's my Captain. The best player I've got. The COMMITTEE MEMBERS get to their feet and walk out.
CLOUGH's face: OVER THIS: the sound of a ringing phone. T sound of a familiar voice at the other end..
Hello?
CLOUGH in his cheap hotel-room. PETER TAYLOR's voice the other end..
I suppose you've heard!
TAYLOR freezes, hearing the voice, (we intercut as necess for the remainder of the call)..
God...what time is it?
Suspended for eleven bloody games!!
I know. You're buggered. Billy Bremner's the heart and soul of that team.
Plus Mike Jones and Eddie Gray are injured.
Like I said. You're buggered.
What do I do, Pete? I need new players. Tell me who to buy.
No, Brian.
Help me. C'mon, we'll sort this place out together. You and me. Turn it around.
It's too late. I'd have helped you once. But not now. Not after what was said. We're on our own now. Each man for himself. Remember?
"Click", TAYLOR hangs up. CLOUGH stares at the receiver.
The same sign as earlier. "MR. D. MACKAY - MANAGER". CLOUGH stares at the sign as he parks his car in the spac beside it. A stab in his heart.

CLOUGH walks along a corridor. Sees the PLAYERS training outside. HIS players. DERBY players. To one side, MCGOVERN and O'HARE. CLOUGH looks out at the He winks, discreetly at them. They look back, and nod. Then get back to work. The sound of laughter. The camaraderie of a family. What contrast to Leeds. CLOUGH walks along a corridor with photos on the wall. Fr photos of HIS victories. HIS club. HIS family. HIS home.
CLOUGH walks into the office to see DAVE MACKAY behind hi desk. Who gets to his feet. Extends his hand.
Well, look who it is! Come to raid my larder? Or just missing the place?
McGovern and O'Hare. I've spoken to them on the phone. They want to come and play for me.
Aye, and you can have `em. A hundred and fifty thousand pound for the pair.
Cheeky sod! They're not worth a penny more than seventy.
But you're desperate now, aren't you? Having lost to Stoke and Birmingham.. (a beat)
All, right, since it's you..I'll knock ten grand off.
Give you a hundred grand.
One thirty. Final offer. CLOUGH is about to explode, then..
All right. Done. The two MEN shake hands. Barely. CLOUGH (cont'd)
So? Enjoying yourself?
Two wins from two. What's not to enjoy? You?
Loving it. Different class, Leeds. Proper club. BIG club.
Demand results there, though, Brian.
Hey, it's `Boss' to you.
Not any more.
I bought you when you were crocked, you fat bastard. And gave you the two best years of your career. It will always be `Boss' to you.
CLOUGH walks to the door. He turns, and indicates the des CLOUGH (cont'd)
Ever tempted to burn that bloody desk? Chop it up and burn it?
Why would I do that?
Exorcise the bloody place. Get rid of me.
Why? You're not here anymore, are you? Be a waste of a perfectly good desk.
CLOUGH driving his car. Clenching the steering wheel in f
Fucking Scot.
It's late: JIMMY GORDON with CLOUGH in the bar..
McGovern and O'Hare? Can't believe he actually sold them to you. It must be true, then..
What?
The rumour that he's after buying Duncan Mackenzie. It's why he needs the money.
Who's Duncan Mackenzie? OVER THIS: the sound of a ringing phone...
DUNCAN MACKENZIE, long-haired, chain-smoking, bemused, st in the lobby of the hotel. OVER THIS: we hear...
Is that Duncan Mackenzie?
Yes. This is he.
Now listen to me. You go get your coat and your skates on because you're coming to meet me at the Victoria Hotel in Sheffield in half and hour. And Duncan?
Yes, Mr. Clough.
Bring a bloody pen, because you're signing for Leeds United today.
`Pop', a WAITER uncorks champagne, pours it into glasses. CLOUGH and his three sheepish new signings: MCGOVERN, O'H and DUNCAN MACKENZIE sit uneasily in the bar.

Congratulations, lads!! My first signings for Leeds. My Leeds United. Playing with flair and winning with honour. Winning the `right' way. And winning the admiration of fans all over Europe because...
Because of the way we play.
Because of the way we play!!! MACKENZIE lights a cigarette.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
We're going all the way, lads. Inter Milan, Barcelona. We're going to win silverware Don Revie could only dream of.
Yes, Boss.
And you, Mr. Mackenzie, you scored twenty-eight goals last season. You'll score me twenty-nine goals this.
Yes, Mr. Clough.
Do you know how many goals I scored before I got injured?
I'm sorry, Mr. Clough. I don't.
Two hundred and fifty-one. MCGOVERN and O'HARE privately exchange looks, "Here goes" CLOUGH (cont'd)
Do you know how many games it took me?
I'm sorry, Mr. Clough, I don't.
Have a guess. Go on... O'HARE mouths "Two hundred and seventy-four"..
Three hundred? MCGOVERN closes his eyes, "Moron."
Two hundred and seventy-four! Now what do you think about that?
Is that a record, Mr. Clough?
(rolling eyes)
`Course it's a bloody record. CLOUGH shoots a look to the others.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
You know what ELSE you lot can do that's even more important? You can be my eyes and ears in that dressing room.
Yes, Mr. Clough/Yes, Boss
Need to know what they say about me. Who's making trouble. Who the ringleaders are.
Yes, Mr. Clough.
Want you to help me clear this place out. Make it MY team, understand. OUR team. Clean it up and clear it out once and for all.
Yes, Mr. Clough. CLOUGH indicates MACKENZIE's drink..
Now c'mon, drink up. We're off to meet the press.
Yes, Mr. Clough. MACKENZIE knocks back his champagne..
And Duncan..?
Yes, Mr. Clough?
It's "Boss" from now on. There's a good lad.
Yes, Mr. Clough. CLOUGH sighs and goes. MCGOVERN and O'HARE roll their eye MACKENZIE stubs his cigarette, and hurries after them..

"Flash", photographs are being taken by PRESS of the thre new signings, DUNCAN MCKENZIE, JOHN O'HARE and JOHN MCGOV all wearing Leeds shirts. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: they are being watched from a distan by several Leeds SENIOR players..
CLOUGH walks through a corridor, brushing past JOHNNY GIL BILLY BREMNER and several other SENIOR PLAYERS. An intimidating atmosphere..
What the hell did you buy them for? Waste of bloody money.
Duncan Mackenzie scored twenty-eight goals last season. John O'Hare and John McGovern are both internationals.
We've got two strikers, Alan Clarke and Mick Jones, they're internationals, too.
And one's injured and the other's fucking suspended.
Maybe if you spent a little more time here on the training ground with us, you wouldn't need to buy Derby "rejects". (a beat)
We've a game Saturday. Against Queens Park Rangers. Or had you forgotten?
I haven't forgotten.

Well, you haven't told us a single thing about how QPR will play. Mr Revie would have files and dossiers prepared. Had the reserves playing the Rangers way all week. Had the first team looking out for this and that.

Bollocks to Mr. Revie! You're professional footballers. Stop Stan Bowles! That's all you need to know about QPR. And I don't have to justify myself to you. Not how or when I conduct training. Not who I buy or pick to play.

No. Not to us. But come Saturday afternoon, there'll be 40,000 people here who you DO have to justify yourself, to. GILES, BREMNER et al walk off. CLOUGH left, staring. OVER THIS: a large RRRRROOOAAARRRR. GOAL.
The LEEDS PLAYERS trudge in, after the game. Angry. Heads hung low. Begin to strip off. CAPTION: "QPR 1, Leeds 0." CLOUGH enters. Visibly gutted by the result, but now's no the time to show it..
Sorry, lads. CLOUGH walks round the dressing-room, shaking hands individually, patting PLAYERS on the back... CLOUGH (cont'd)
You were robbed out there today. Broad bloody daylight. That was never a penalty. CLOUGH's tone is sensitive. Tactful. Considerate.
CLOUGH (cont'd)
Stan Bowles?    Diving like that? Man's a disgrace.. But several of the LEEDS PLAYERS refuse his hand. Or free at his touch. Turn away from him.. CLOUGH (cont'd)

I've spoken to the referee already. Given him a piece of my mind. And come Monday morning, mark my word, I shall be taking this further... The LEEDS PLAYERS stare at one another. Shoot one another looks. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Anyway, I want you all to know, I'm not in the slightest bit critical of your performance today. Not a bit of it. You were terrific out there...
NORMAN HUNTER spits in contempt. GILES turns and walks ou into the showers. CLOUGH (cont'd)
I couldn't ask for more effort. Commitment. (tailing off)
Passion. The LEEDS PLAYERS follow. Finally O'HARE and MCGOVERN, to A deathly silence. CLOUGH is left alone in the dressing-r OVER THIS: the sound of a ringing telephone. A gruff VOIC answers..
Hello?
It's the middle of the night. CLOUGH speaks into the phon visibly the worse for wear from alcohol...
You must be loving this. Loving every minute.
DON REVIE's face, half-asleep. Visibly irritated. He sits in bed. A stout Yorkshire matron wakes beside him.
Who is this?
Watching it all fall apart. It's Brian Clough.
What?
They won't play for me. Your boys. Your bastard sons. And never will.
Are you drunk, man? It's two in the morning. What do you want? Why are you ringing me here?
They're loyal to you. Thought you'd like to know that. Loyal to Big Daddy Don..
For God's sake go to sleep. Where's you dignity, man? And don't call here again. "Click", REVIE hangs up. CLOUGH stares at the receiver.
The Leeds Coach arrives at Derby. Hydraulic brakes hissssssss. Doors open. Boots, shoes, walk down steps. DON REVIE, SYD OWEN and the Leeds PLAYERS disembark.

head_text.subj: HARVEY, REANEY, CHERRY, BREMNER, HUNTER, LORMIER, CLARKE,

text: JORDAN, GILES, GRAY walk towards the Derby dressing-rooms
SAM LONGSON stands by the window, looking out into the ca park. He sees the Leeds United PLAYERS. Reads their mood.
Their faces. Their focus. Their murderous intent. A flicker of concern on SAM LONGSON's face. He thinks, th calls out to his SECRETARY..
Get me today's team sheet, will you? He lets the curtain fall..
SAM LONGSON walks through corridors of Elland Road, carry the team sheet. Walking towards the dressing-rooms. He tu a corner and runs into CLOUGH..
What's up, Uncle Sam? Bit below stairs for you here, isn't it? Taken a wrong turn somewhere?
Just seen the team sheet. Hinton, O'Hare, Todd, Mackay. (looks left and right)
That's our strongest side.
Of course it's our strongest side. It's Leeds United. Would you prefer I sent out the apprentices?
We're at Juventus mid-week. Semi-final of the European Cup. Biggest night in the club's history!! Couldn't you just field...
What?
Y'know...
A weaker side? Am I hearing right? Is the CHAIRMAN of this football club seriously asking his manager to LOSE?
You know what I mean..
Against their biggest rivals?

The Chairman of this football club is asking his manager to be pragmatic. Manage his resources. Prioritise. We've embarked on a huge program of refurbishment and improvements. New stands. Better floodlights. We need a good run in Europe to pay for it.
I'm going to pretend I didn't hear a word of this. CLOUGH turns to walk away. LONGSON calls after him..
(checking watch)
We've still got twenty minutes before kick-off. I'd reconsider if I were you. I wouldn't want my employer to be unhappy..
My employer?
Chairman of Derby County. And Chairman LONG before you ever showed up.

That's right. You were Chairman of Derby County before I came here. I remember that. When Derby County were at the fucking foot of the Second Division, when nobody had heard of them for twenty years and nobody had heard of Sam bloody Longson ever. Full stop. And that's where you'd still fucking be if it wasn't for me; at the foot of the bloody Second Division, where nobody remembered you and nobody had heard of you. There would BE no Derby County without me, no league title, no Champions of England; not without Brian Clough. A door opens and PETER TAYLOR walks out in time to hear..
I'm going to give you some good advice, Brian Clough.
LON GSON (cont'd)

No matter how good you think you are, or how clever, or how many fancy new friends you make on the telly, the reality of footballing life is this: the Chairman is the boss, then come the directors, then the secretary, then the fans, then the players, and finally, last of all, bottom-of-the- heap, lowest of the low, the one in the end we can all without, is the bloody manager. LONGSON turns and storms off. TAYLOR looks at CLOUGH..
What have you done now? CLOUGH doesn't answer, and storms off in the opposite direction. TAYLOR is left alone, visibly anxious.

CLOUGH watches from the touch-line as the game is in progress. "CRASH", a Leeds PLAYER scythes into a Derby PLAYER. "BEEEP", the referee blows his whistle. CLOUGH an leaps off his bench in fury. Shouting abuse..
You're a bloody disgrace! You should be in the book for that, Cherry! "BEEEP", the referee blows his whistle. REVIE smiles to himself as a Derby PLAYER is carried off on a stretcher. CLOUGH (cont'd)

You're an animal. A fucking animal, Hunter! SAM LONGSON watches from the director's box. He closes hi eyes. PETER TAYLOR witnesses this.. "CRUNCH", another brutal tackle, another whistle. Another Derby PLAYER hobbles off the pitch. Blood streaming from cut to his head.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
I'll see you in fucking court, Lorimer! CLOUGH's eyes meet REVIE's eyes along the touchline.
Afterwards: the LEEDS and DERBY players file off the pitc BREMNER brushes roughly past CLOUGH...
(under his breath)
Good luck in Europe.. CLOUGH turns, `What?" BREMNER, GILES, HUNTER, LORIMER car on walking down the tunnel. Laughing to themselves.. CLOUGH is joined by TAYLOR and JIMMY GORDON.

Afterwards: the Derby dressing-room looks like the Emerge Room at a hospital.. Casualties. Blood. Stitches. Swellings. At least half-a-d PLAYERS are injured. Some on stretchers. CLOUGH stares in horror at the wreckage from the doorway. LONGSON appears beside him. Stares at CLOUGH..
You fucking idiot. LONGSON turns and walks away. CLOUGH turns to survey the carnage in the dressing-room. Like a battlefield. CLOUGH's eyes meet TAYLOR's.
The most important night in Derby's history as the Derby players arrive in Turin to play against mighty Juventus..
BARBARA CLOUGH and the children. Huddled together round t television. Eating supper. Watching the Juventus game on
There's Dad, look! BARBARA and the KIDS watch intently. But JUVENTUS score o goal. Then another. The final whistle. JUVENTUS win 3-1. BARBARA (cont'd)
Pity. BARBARA gets to her feet... BARBARA (cont'd)
All right. Bed time! Everyone clean your teeth!
Wait..! Look..! ON TV: CLOUGH is in the tunnel. Speaking to a television REPORTER.
Disappointed? Not a bit. My players were heroic out there tonight. Effectively we were playing the Italian champions with a reserve team. That many of our first team are injured...
CLOUGH continues. PETER TAYLOR stands beside him, visibly pale, stressed...

...it's what happens if you have a Chairman who authorizes a multi- million pound refurbishment of the director's box and hospitality suites before he pays for a proper squad. Suppose it depends on your priorities. Players or prawn sandwiches? I know which I'd prefer. I know which honest, working class Derby supporters would prefer, too.. A commotion breaks out. TV JOURNALISTS ask questions, sen a great story. CLOUGH continues answering as, beside him, (unseen by anyone else)... ...TAYLOR is white-faced, holding his chest.
CLOUGH pouring brandy into a glass. DUNCAN MACKENZIE, JOH O'HARE, and JOHN MCGOVERN sit in front of him. Visibly uncomfortable.
Billy Bremner, Boss.
Who else?
Norman Hunter.
Who else?
Eddie Gray.
Who else?
Peter Lorimer.
What are they saying? This falls to MACKENZIE, who knocks back his drink. Tremb hands. Dutch courage.
That you're never here. (a beat)
That they're worried about the future. (a beat)
That you're just going to fill the place with more Derby players.
And that all thing's considered they were all a lot happier under...
Under who? MCGOVERN dries. Cannot find the words.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Don Revie?
MACKENZIE, MCGOVERN, O'HARE avoid his eyes.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
Is that what they say?
Yes, Boss.
That he's the boss? The Guvnor? The Capi di Tutti Fucking Capi?
Yes, Boss.
And that they miss the bingo.
The bingo?
And the carpet bowls.
Carpet bloody bowls?
It helps them relax before a game. MCGOVERN and O'HARE stare at one another..

That it, Boss? Can we go now? CLOUGH stares, lost in thought: the three PLAYERS go. The door closes. CLOUGH is left alone. Then he gets up, and in a terrifying flash of rage, picks his glass and throws it against the wall..

CLOUGH walks out into the car park, then he stops in his tracks when he sees.. JOHNNY GILES, BILLY BREMNER and NORMAN HUNTER (among othe with their GIRLFRIENDS and WIVES and KIDS, being shown br new cars by a SPONSOR. CLOUGH takes JIMMY GORDON aside..
What's all this?
Club cars. Complimentary for the senior payers. Brand new. CLOUGH sees BREMNER, GILES and HUNTER trying out the spor cars. His smile fades. He walks up to the REP from the CA FIRM..
Nice to meet you, pet. Now, you can take your lovely sports cars, and put `em back on your transporter..
What?
What are you talking about? These are ours!

You'll have complimentary cars when you deserve a compliment. Right now you don't deserve a complimentary bicycle between you. CLOUGH takes the KEYS and gives them to the REPRESENTATIV CLOUGH (cont'd)
Complimentary cars when you're not suspended.. (indicates BREMNER)
...and when you lot start winning some games.. (indicated GILES and
CLOUGH goes back to his own car.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
If I had my way, you'd WALK to the ground and back every game.. CLOUGH gets into his car, and roars out, past glowering BREMNER, glowering GILES, glowering HUNTER, glowering GIRLFRIENDS and WIVES.
CLOUGH's car pulls up outside his house in Derby. He clos his eyes. Breathes a private sigh of relief. Home. At las Safe. Surrounded by people who love him.
CLOUGH walks into his house.
What are you doing here? Aren't you supposed to be in that hotel in Leeds?
I couldn't stand it for another night. CLOUGH takes off his coat...
What? So you drove all the way? What time will you have to get up in the morning...
Half five. CLOUGH bends down. Kisses his wife. CLOUGH (cont'd)
You smell nice.
Do I?
Forgotten what a woman smells like. BARBARA strokes his head.
Not like bloody men. That's for sure.
CLOUGH looks into his SONS' room. The eldest is fast asle but the youngest says, `Dad?'
You still awake? You should be asleep.
Tell us a joke, Dad?
A joke? All right. There's this bloke walking about in London, when all of a sudden, the city gets hit by a Russian `A' bomb. Booooooooom. CLOUGH sits down, strokes his son's head.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
And all the buildings have fallen down. And all the people are dead. And now this bloke is the only man left in the whole of London. CLOUGH continues stroking his son's hair.. CLOUGH (cont'd)
And he suddenly feels very, very lonely because there's no one else to talk to. Nobody else but him. CLOUGH's SON falls asleep. CLOUGH doesn't notice.. CLOUGH (cont'd)

So he decides that he's had enough, that he can't bear being this lonely, and so he climbs up to the top of the one building still standing. The Post Office Tower. And then he jumps off. And he's falling down, down and down and down, the sixteenth floor, the fifteenth floor, the fourteenth, and that's when he hears the phone ringing... CLOUGH looks down. And gets two unexpected shocks. The first is that his SON is already asleep. The second i there is a tear running down his own cheek.
The LEEDS PLAYERS clatter off the pitch. Covered in mud. Walking in silence. No smiles. Heads hung low..
JIMMY GORDON is waiting for CLOUGH..
The Chairman wants to see you. Said it was important. Right away.
CLOUGH's face: already fearing the worst.

CLOUGH walks along the corridor. Past the photographs on wall. The trophies in the cabinets. The pictures of a smi DON REVIE - mocking him. CLOUGH shoots his cuffs. Rolls his neck. A boxer on his w to the ring. A gladiator on his way to the circus. He knocks on the door, and walks in. MANNY CUSSINS, SAM BOLTON and a third man. A stranger.
About bloody time.
Where you been? I was about to send out a search party.
Look, Mr. Cussins, I know it's not been the best of starts, but in my defence, there are a couple of things I'd like to say...
This is Martin Hughes. He runs Mercedes here in the North.
(double-takes)
What?
We hear that's what you like to drive. A Mercedes?
It's..what I used to drive at Derby. Yes.

Well, we can't have Leeds United being outdone by Derby County, can we? So Martin here is going to take you over to his showroom and get you sorted out. They begin to walk to the door. CUSSINS puts his arm roun CLOUGH...
CUSSINS (cont'd)

Also we figured if you were sitting in a spanking new car yourself, you might be a little more bloody lenient with your senior players, who've kicked off, as you can imagine - being denied what's rightfully theirs.
Never come between a footballer and his motor!
No.
Especially not Billy bloody Bremner. CLOUGH smiles nervously, visibly relieved...
Is that it, then?
Why? You look white as a ghost, man. CUSSINS tightens his grip again, arm round CLOUGH. Unmistakably intimidating.. CUSSINS (cont'd)
What did you think we'd asked you up here for? CUSSINS's eyes. CLOUGH's eyes. The air crackling with men and intent.
CLOUGH visits PETER TAYLOR in a large, crowded ward of ol infirm, dying people. It's a shock.
Heart attack, eh?
Had it three weeks ago, they reckon.
TAYLOR (cont'd)
They ran all kinds of tests. Asked me about my diet and my family history.
TAY LOR (cont'd)
I told them the only thing they needed to know was that I share my professional life with Brian Clough. That seemed to satisfy them. CLOUGH manages a smile. Moved. TAYLOR (cont'd)
I'm only half-joking, you know. Have we still got jobs?
We have. Longson's tried to put a gagging order on me, of course. (mimics)
"Any further utterances in public or appearances in the media by Brian Clough will be met with instant dismissal."
Well, I hope you take notice. And act accordingly.
Would you like to hear my contrite reply? CLOUGH pulls out a letter.. CLOUGH (cont'd)

"Due to the complete breakdown in communication with the chairman, Peter Taylor and I find it is impossible to continue our good work for Derby County. We therefore wish to tender our resignations with immediate effect."
(horrified)
What do you think?
I don't want to resign.
No. Nor do I. Don't worry, they'll never let us. We just won them the championship. But it will strengthen our position and force them to get rid of Longson.
What? Oh, no, Brian. They'll never do THAT. He's Chairman.
I can't do it, Pete. I can't work with my hands tied, a Chairman telling me what I can or cannot do.
You're picking the wrong enemy. The enemy's not Longson. It's Revie. And your obsession with Leeds.
Don't be daft. We won the league, Pete. We're top dogs in Derby now. And Longson can't stand it. That's the problem.

No, it's not. It's YOU. This monster in you. This mad ambition. It comes and goes. Sometimes it's good...a fire, that stirs everything up, and then there's this...this thing that takes you over...and destroys everything that is good in your life. TAYLOR's face... TAYLOR (cont'd)
Please tell me this letter is just a draft. You haven't sent it. Because I'll be out in a couple of days...let me talk to them.
"Crash", door fly open. CLOUGH storms down a corridor.
"Bang", CLOUGH crashes into the boardroom. When they see CLOUGH, voices fall silent. They stiffen..
What are you doing? You weren't supposed to accept our resignations.
`Shouldn't bloody well offer them, then. CLOUGH turns to the other DIRECTORS...
I only did because of HIM! (points at LONGSON)
You can't get rid of us. It'd be a disaster for the club. For the whole of Derby.
You can't keep shooting your mouth off the way you have been...or issuing these ultimatums.. The board stare at one another, avoid eye contact.. LONGSON (cont'd)
With great reluctance your resignations have been accepted.
You can't do this! It's madness!
The decision stands. And don't even think of a settlement. You're getting nowt.
We're going to create a footballing dynasty here. Derby could be one of the greats alongside United, Liverpool, Leeds.. CLOUGH stands in the middle of the room. Speechless.
Car keys on the table and out! CLOUGH stares in disbelief at the other BOARD MEMBERS..
Does none of you have the guts to stop this?

Now! And don't show your faces here again! CLOUGH stares in disbelief at the assembled board members Derby County.. ROY KIRKLAND, ROBERTSON-KING, KEELING, SAM LONGSON, et al Blazers and brass buttons. The sound of clearing throats.
News footage: Prime Minister Ted Heath announcing blackou due to the oil crisis. Britain is plunged into power-cuts And total darkness. Three days a week.

TAYLOR walks through the open door. A meeting is underway in the CLOUGH house. In the hall: CLOUGH's three CHILDREN stare through banist railings.. The smoke-filled front room is packed with FRIENDS, RELATIVES, LAWYERS, DERBY COUNTY CLUB EMPLOYEES.. Newspapers are strewn over the table. CLOUGH sits in the corner, being given counsel by SOLICITORS. JIMMY GORDON r out a letter from the DERBY PLAYERS...

"To the directors of Derby County Football Club. We, the undersigned players, are unanimous in our support and respect for Mr. Clough and Mr. Taylor and ask that they be reinstated as manager and assistant manager of the club." Cheers and celebrations. CLOUGH is congratulated. Handsha Hair ruffled.. JIMMY (cont'd)
"Signed by John O'Hare, Roy MacFarland, Colin Todd, Archie Gemmill, Kevin Hector, Alan Hinton.."
But not Dave Mackay.
Silence. All voices stop. Heads turn. TAYLOR (cont'd)
Who's just accepted the job. Deathly silence. The crowds part. CLOUGH sits up, and stares..
What? Dave MACKAY?
It's in the evening paper.
I signed that fat fuck - saved his professional life. Gave him two more years as a player, as my captain. Dave Mackay? (a beat)
He wouldn't fucking DARE! CLOUGH sees the paper. "MACKAY TO BE DERBY MANAGER". CLOU face. Devastated.
Why did you do it? I love this place, Brian. I'm happy here. So are you.

It's not over yet, Pete. The lawyers are issuing a writ tomorrow. Against Longson. The players are calling a meeting. There's talk of them coming out on strike. There's protest marches scheduled for this week-end.
Why couldn't you just have kept your mouth shut? We'll never find anywhere like this again. TAYLOR stares. Worried. At that moment, BARBARA sticks he head outside.
(holding phone)
Mike Bamber on the phone?
Who's Mike Bamber??
Manager of Brighton and Hove Albion. Someone who wants to offer us a job.
OVER THIS: the sound of a referee's whistle..

With a loud ROAR the game against Luton gets under way. CLOUGH takes his seat alone in the dugout. Unseen by him, the stands behind him... DON REVIE arrives, shaking hands, taking a seat. Immediately, as soon as they see REVIE, the LEEDS FANS st cheering, "There's only one Don Revie.." CLOUGH turns, to see REVIE. Waving back. Acknowledging th crowd.
